title: 109_s2695
content: The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 aims to make research findings funded by the Federal Government accessible to the public. Congress recognizes the importance of sharing research results to advance science and benefit society. The Act defines a "Federal agency" as an Executive agency under title 5, United States Code. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies with over $100,000,000 in research expenditures to develop a public access policy for research papers funded by the government. This policy includes submitting final manuscripts of research papers to the agency, incorporating peer review changes, and replacing the final manuscript with the published version. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates Federal agencies to ensure public access to research papers funded by the government. This includes incorporating peer review changes, replacing the final manuscript with the published version, providing free online access to manuscripts within 6 months, creating an online bibliography, and ensuring long-term preservation and public access to research papers. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies to provide public access to research papers funded by the government. This includes creating an online bibliography of accessible research papers and ensuring long-term preservation and public access to published findings in digital repositories. Each Federal research public access policy applies to researchers employed or funded by the Federal agency, ensuring public domain works are marked as such and made immediately available. The policy also utilizes Government licenses for final manuscript reproduction. Exclusions exist for certain cases. The Federal research public access policy includes the creation and reservation of a Government license for the use of final manuscripts for Federal purposes. Exclusions apply to certain types of research and authors who do not submit their work to journals. Nothing in the policy affects rights under patent or copyright law. The Federal research public access policy excludes certain types of research and authors who do not submit their work to journals. It does not affect rights under patent or copyright law. Federal agencies are required to submit an annual report on the policy's effectiveness to specific committees in Congress. The Federal research public access policy requires federal agencies to submit an annual report to Congress on the effectiveness of providing free online access to research papers funded by the agency. The report must include a statement on the policy's effectiveness, a list of published papers, a corresponding list of papers available online, and a summary of the time between publication and public availability. The Federal agency must provide a report to Congress on the effectiveness of the research public access policy, including a statement on its effectiveness, a list of published papers, a corresponding list of papers available online, and a summary of the time between publication and public availability. The agency must make this information available to the public on its website.
